data.title: The Dutch Cemetery at Chinsurah: A Glimpse into the Colonial Past

data.text:
Nestled on the banks of the Hooghly River in West Bengal, lies the historic town of Chinsurah, home to one of the most fascinating relics of colonial history—the Dutch Cemetery. This cemetery is a testament to the Dutch presence in Bengal during the 17th and 18th centuries and provides a poignant window into a period marked by trade, exploration, and cultural exchanges between Europe and India.

The Dutch East India Company, known as the Vereenigde Oostindische Compagnie (VOC), was established in 1602 to manage Dutch trade in Asia. The VOC’s influence extended across the Indian subcontinent, and Chinsurah, originally a modest village, emerged as a significant Dutch trading post in 1625. The strategic location of Chinsurah, near the Hooghly River, made it an ideal hub for trade, particularly in spices, textiles, and indigo.

During the 17th and 18th centuries, Chinsurah flourished under Dutch control, with the establishment of factories, warehouses, and administrative buildings. The town became a microcosm of Dutch life, where traders, soldiers, and their families lived and worked. The Dutch Cemetery was established during this period, serving as the final resting place for many of these European settlers.

The town’s fortunes changed hands several times, reflecting the turbulent history of colonial India. In 1825, Chinsurah was ceded to the British in exchange for the island of Sumatra in Indonesia, and it became part of the British Empire. Despite the change in power, the legacy of the Dutch period is still evident in the architecture, culture, and, most poignantly, in the Dutch Cemetery. The earliest recorded burial at the cemetery is that of Cornelis de Jonge (Jong) who died in the year 1743, the last recorded burial was held in 1887, that of Emma Draper.

The tombs are an eclectic mix of styles, reflecting the diverse backgrounds of those buried here. Some are simple, with modest inscriptions, while others are grand and elaborate, adorned with intricate carvings and epitaphs in Dutch and Latin. One of the unique features of the cemetery is the presence of pyramid-shaped tombs, which are relatively rare in Indian cemeteries (although many can also be seen at South Park Street Cemetery in Kolkata). These tombs, inspired by classical European designs, stand out against the backdrop of the lush greenery and add to the cemetery’s mystique.

Mary Diemer (b.1759 d. 1782)

Daughter of Charles Weston Esq (who is buried in South Park Street cemetery), she married J. C. Diemer V.D.M. in 1776. They had one son, John James Diemer, who was baptised in Calcutta in 1776.

Full Epitaph:

Sacred to the memory of Mrs. Mary Diemer Second Daughter of Char.s Weston Esq. of Calcutta who in the Bloom of her Life Was Broken off by a lingering Disorder At Bandell the 3.d of June 1782. In the 23rd Year of her Age. ….. She was in her Life, plain and open, Humble in her mind Grave and modest in her conversation, Constant in her friendship; Untainted by the fluctuating fashion of the Age sincere in her Piety to God; Sympathizing with her fellow creatures Patient & resigned under all her sufferings An obedient Daughter A faithful Wife A tender Mother Beloved & esteemed in her Life Lamented & regretted in her Death Especially By her affectionate Husband J. C. Diemer. V.D.M S. Oldham ……………. In memory of these Daughters Dear Who grieve the heart & force the Parent’s tear, So soon by Angels snatched away To dwell in Reigns of eternal day They weep no more the mourn or sigh …. like them to live like them to die.

Pieter Brueys (b.1730 d. 1783)

Husband of the infamous Susana Anna Maria Verkirk, who is buried in a grand tomb near to the cemetery. He was Grand Master of the Chinsurah Masonic Lodge some time before the year 1774, and was Governor of Chinsurah at the time of his death.

Full Epitaph:

Hier rust Pieter Brueys, in leeven Opperkoopman en Hoofde, Administrateur te Chinsurah, Overleeden den XXIII Augustus MDCCLXXXIII oud zynde LII jaaren IX maanden en XVII dagen.

The epitaph roughly translates to:

Here rests Pieter Brueys, Chief Merchant and Administrator of Chinsurah, deceased on 23th August 1783, at the age of 52 years, 9 months and 17 days.

Maria Wiemer (Wymer) (d.1821)

Wife of Captain G.P. Wymer of the 61st Regiment. Her tomb is notable for the presence of a Masonic compass with stars on a coat-of-arms.

Lucas Jurriaanz Zuydland (b.1698 d.1766)

Jurriaanz Zuydland was a naval captain and warehouse supervisor. Born in Niewolda on 21 March 1698, the dates would indicate that Zuydland was indeed the Dutch commodore who was involved in the only naval battle between European ships on the Hooghly river. Not many know about the Battle of Biderra where Dutch troops fought those of Robert Clive in an attempt to check the British East India Company’s growing influence. In 1759, the Dutch landed seven hundred European soldiers and eight hundred ‘Bugis’ (Malays) at Sankrail on the opposite bank of the river to Calcutta. The Dutch had separated their ships from their troops and Clive decided to fight them both on water and on land. On land, the Dutch troops suffered a crushing defeat at Biderra and just a day before, the Dutch and British ships also fought what was perhaps the only naval engagement on the river Hooghly.

Lucas Zuydland is mentioned by John Henry Grose in his A Voyage to the East Indies (1772) as the ‘ship-master of the Dutch factory’. Sir George Forrest also mentions a James Zuydland who was the commodore of the Dutch fleet of seven ships that lost to the British in the engagement on the Hooghly, writing that :

‘…the Dutch fought with their national obstinate courage. The deck of the Vlissingen, the commodore’s ship, was strewed with the dead and wounded. James Zuydland, the commodore, could fight no more‘

Full Epitaph:

Ter gedagtenisse van Wylen den Hr. Lucas Jurriaanz Zuydland in leeven Capitain ter zee equipage en Baanm, gebooren te Nieuwolda 21 Maart Ao. 1698. Obit den 25 Octobr. Ao. 1766

William Wood (b.1808 d.1846)

Lieutenant in the 95th Foot who on 8 May 1835 became a Captain in the 69th Foot by purchase.

Full Epitaph:

To the memory of captain William Wood of n.m. 39th Foot Who died at Chinsurah on the 26th January 1846 aged 39 years. This Monument is erected by his brother officers , as a mark of their esteem and regard.

Other notable people buried here include :

Daniel Anthony Overbeek (b.1765 d.1840)

The last Dutch Governor of Chinsurah, who oversaw the town until it was ceded to the British in 1825.

Francis Albertus

A notable Dutch merchant whose extensive trade networks helped establish Chinsurah as a major trading hub.

The Dutch Cemetery at Chinsurah is more than just a burial ground; it is a cultural and historical landmark that offers insights into the colonial past of Bengal. It stands as a symbol of the Dutch contributions to the region’s economic and cultural landscape. The cemetery also highlights the cosmopolitan nature of Chinsurah during the colonial era, where Europeans and Indians coexisted and influenced each other’s lives.

Preserving the Dutch Cemetery has been a challenge due to various factors such as environmental conditions, neglect, and lack of funds. However, there have been concerted efforts by heritage conservationists, historians, and the local community to maintain and restore this historical site. The Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has also played a significant role in the preservation efforts, ensuring that this important piece of history is not lost to time.

While the Dutch Cemetery at Chinsurah is an incredibly interesting place to visit, nothing can compare to South Park Street Cemetery in Kolkata, which simply cannot be missed if you plan to spend any time in the city.
